pr_title: Jonmv/throw during prepare with disallowed config change actions

timeline.message: Use proper ValidationId instead of their String names in ConfigChangeAction subclasses
Model disallowable actions separately, and collect and throw these in validation

timeline.bodyText: Given this usage, I think it would be simpler to just put validationId on ConfigChangeAction as an Optional.
timeline.author: bratseth

replies.bodyText: I suppose that's equally not super-obvious, but good enough, and a bit simpler, yes. Can't even remember why I didn't do this. Probably no good reason. It's "you must provide a validatoin id for implementations which may block deployment", in any case.
replies.author: jonmv

replies.bodyText: Ah, so it's because making it optional makes you have to .get() or .orElseThrow() to get the name() in the child interfaces, which is ugly. It's clearer with a separate interface, although more verbose.
replies.author: jonmv

replies.bodyText: Should just remove the allowed() altogether, since it no longer serves a purpose with these changes. Guess there'' be some more work here, then ...
replies.author: jonmv

timeline.bodyText: Just to repeat my standard comment to your code: These stream statements that does everything are like a long sentence with lots of subsentences. It's easier to read shorter sentences, especially since it makes you name the thing they produce.
timeline.author: bratseth

replies.bodyText:
But.
I.
Like.
Long.
Sentences.
I appreciate your comment on this; you're probably not the only one, so I will try to adjust for readability.
replies.author: jonmv

timeline.author: bratseth

timeline.message: Break long stream statement to provide intermediary name
Add Optional<ValidationId> to ConfigActionChange and use to validate actions
Remove "allowed" from config change actions (+ wiring) — allowed if not thrown
